reviewText:
Product received for free

*recieved free via Twitter through @ProjectMQ; Indie Dev supporter*
[review written on behalf of my own personal opinion]

8/10 Chain Total[pros]
Great arcade style, side-scrolling shooter
Great Mech Weaponry Development (so far; could be room for improvement)
Easy-to-Understand GUI/No Learning-Curve
Great Mech Suit/Battle Mech concept and art
Customizable gameplay modes (even save them)
Multiple modes of play
Would be willing to pay for it for friends
Simple & easy to pick up & play
[cons]
Mech Weaponry is a pinch cliche (could use more variety)
Dialogue could use some more depth (possibly even provide a multi-linear story)
Achievements are easily obtainable (should make some either a pinch more difficult, or some extra ones that are more difficult)
Too much fun, not enough updates

reviewText:
This is an early review, I will update as I progress further in.

Game initially launched on what I consider my secondary monitor (as it has much lower specs than my new one), this was a simple remedy and I set the game to windowed, dragged it over to the good one and went back to fullscreen. It didn't detect the max refresh rate or resolution, so I relaunched the game and all was well. I did have to set it up to the maximum resolution though.

On to the game itself. This appears to be a co-op bullet hell that you can customize the experience of. The graphics are crisp, the music is catchy, and it looks to support both K&M and Xbox style controllers (based on the graphics shown, though I admit I don't have a Dualshock 4 to test with).

On my system, (2600K @ 4.3Ghz, 16GB DDR3 1600 CL9, and a GTX 980) it runs beautifully at 2560x1440, I can't detect any framerate drops, but I'm also using a G-Sync monitor.

Character selection is small, but the items within them are significant, I look forward to pressing on and figuring out what my favorite options are.

Back to the Galaxy I go now!

reviewText:
This is not a review of the game, it's a comment on the Dev team.

I mentioned to the Dev that I love games like this, but being hemiplegic limits me to only being able to play games that have mouse-movement. It was just an offhanded (pun) comment to explain a question I posted.

Two days later, the Devs sent me a message saying they were able to add a way to use mouse movement. They rewrote their game's control scheme just so I could play.

When people  talk about contact they've had with Devs, it's very often negative, highlighting garbage games, dishonest forum activities, scams in Greenlight, etc. That stuff makes it easy to forget that there are some who genuinely care about the quality of their game and about customer support.

Somebody who would go out of their way like this, unsolicited, for a single potential customer...  you can't beat that.
voteText: 650 of 659 people (99%) found this review helpful 8 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This key was obtained from the developer for the purposes of review

Summary:
Solid across the board is the name of the game with Stardust Galaxy Warriors. It's not a game that takes it self too seriously, as you fight everything from a giant talking asteroid to a giant disco ball. What stands out here is the customization and options that are available. Your weapon load outs will play to specific play styles that will do well in parts of levels but not in others, and it helps that the local co-op can play to the game's strengths in question. The customization of fire rates, enemy durability and power ups help to create an experience that can work for any player in the end, giving challenge for those SHMUP pros while scaling back the experience for those who need a little help. Also: props to the fantastic soundtrack here: it's the highlight of the game and frankly makes me recommend the soundtrack as a purchase in of itself, even if you don't like SHMUPs. Does the game's combat over time drag a tiny bit? Yes it does, but in the end, for a 10 dollar title, you can't get much better then the bang for buck that this game provides.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_rkwYRPnZg

Lists:
+:
Customization options for gameplay is one of the strongest in the genre this year, or of many SHMUP like games I've played. Customization of fire rates, enemy durability, and what power ups do makes a game that can tailor itself to you specifically, if you put the time into it. While it can screw with the balance, the default selections do a good job to balance, and it's your decision in the end.
Fantastic Soundtrack. Well worth a look by itself.
Weapon and Mech selections make a huge difference, as you can really change up your playstyle based on what your selection is. Coop choices makes a difference.
Some backgrounds are fantastic (the water level in particular). The graphics options are great for a game of this cost, and while it doesn't take every opportunity for the visual style to come through, it's pretty fantastic.
The controls are solid.
The 4th wall breaking humor does the job. It's a cheesy storyline, but hey, did you expect otherwise?
-:
The Gauntlet mode could use a little bit more punch in the end. It feels very similar after a couple of plays. Over time, the game does have slight trouble in variety.
Boss patterns needs a little bit more as they repeat too often.
It's hard to see the detail on the Mechs that they put on them
Like other games in the genre, sometimes there's too much on the screen, and the explosions and bullets can get lost in the visuals.

reviewText:
A solid little title with a only a few flaws, easily compensated by the very reasonable asking price.

As a Shmup Vet, I approve. 8/10

Pros
- Great soundtrack
- Fun 4 player action
- Visually nice for the most part (backgrounds could use some work at points)
- Tough
- Easy to pick up and play
- Ability to greatly customise game variables can make interesting challenges.

Cons
- Little depth with RPG elements (They kinda feel tacked on)
- Slight Balance Issues
- No online play
- Chat box gets in the way of the screen during gameplay

reviewText:
Pros:
* Mechs have well defined roles (tank, ranged dps, melee dps, and evasion) which allows for synergy between players (tanks deflecting bullets and making everyone invincible to help those who are less familiar with this type of arcade-style game, sniper marking targets to take more damage from all sources, melee dps slowing time for everyone, ...)
* Good amount of customization between picking a mech, a main weapon, and a sub weapon, which are all available immediately. Also frequent upgrades (usually 2) in the middle of levels that allow you to build towards your defined style (such as being a sniper and picking up crit upgrades) as well as a shop at the end of each level that allows for spending points towards more upgrades.
* Tons of game customization (enemy durability, player shot speed, hibox radiuses, spawn rate, fire rate... just about all low level manipulation you can think of). Lots of presets available, so you can easily switch between 5 difficulties' worth of settings, as well as extra presets like Iron Man" where you have 0% shield multiplier.
* Lots of environments - from frozen skies to exploding suns
hoursPlayed: there's 10 locations in all with quite a bit of variety.\n* Can jump right in with the gauntlet mode - basically a never-ending mode (well
voteText:
until you die) where you go for the high score.

Cons:
* Story dialogue / plot is seemingly intentionally bad

Wish I could turn it off entirely.\n* Would really benefit from having online multiplayer (as well as would probably sell a ton more copies. I know I'd be able to get some more friends to play it with me if it had online).\n* Achievements would be a nice touch
votesHelpful:
as it would give me more reason to play and try out all the mechs / weapons solo (and more reason to spend time in gauntlet mode).

Other:

reviewText:
This is an excellent sidescrolling single-player or co-op shmup. I have only played solo so far. I imagine with 4 people playing the action is quite hectic. You select a mech and have several loadout choices for each mission. Missions are done in three stages, at the completion of each stage you are awarded a choice between 3 upgrades that improve attack power, defense, shield regeneration or the speed you acquire special attacks. At the completion of a mission you can spend your mission bonus to buy more upgrades from a vendor.

Controls are very tight and the game is well-balanced, not over-the-top difficulty like some of the borderline sado-masochistic shmups you can find on Steam.

Overall lots of fun and worth considering in a genre that is filled with good options.

reviewText:
A game with mechs that use big guns, swords and superpowers.

What? You need more than that? Really? Oh well, fine:

SGW is a fast paced single player/co-op sidescroller shoot 'em up with light hearted humor along the way. The mechs all get a primary and secondary weapon to use(primary one being mostly something fast like a minigun and secondary something heavier like a grenade launcher) and they also have a melee attack to slash through enemies with. Every mech also gets their own distortion ability(superpower) and another special attack(like Silver Wolf can make a quick dodge dash). Several difficulties to choose from and if you aren't content with the base ones, make your own to use. There is a campaign mode where you progress through several maps, varied enemies/bosses and get upgrades along the way and then theres a gauntlet mode which goes on until you die(or get tired). Fully playable alone or with some friends, especially due to quick and easy customization of difficulty. The developers are also very responsive to feedback and are quick to fix whatever bugs or issues might come up. And the music is great.

In short:
Pros:
-custom difficulty
-great soundtrack
-quick to get into, everything is available right away
-nice and varied visuals
-funny random humor
-responsive devs
-varied weapons and mechs

Cons:
-no online multiplayer

Overall a fun and fast game, more content on the way has been mentioned already.

reviewText:
So I played this game for about 10 minutes.

Great graphics. 4 different robot soldiers you can play as. great music. You can actually permanently level up these guys in terms of critical damage, base damage, shields, weapons, etc. and mix and match different guns and attachments for those guns. I can highly recommend this game based on these 10 minutes, AND the fact that it is under 10 bucks. I can definitely see myself playing this with 3 other people WHICH YOU CAN.

The only downside I can find so far is the lack of achievements. I would love to see upgrade achievements and achievements for slaughtering thousands and thousands of space rocks.

reviewText: Short, sweet, and fun as hell, Stardust Galaxy Warriors has honestly been the most fun I've had in a while.  I'd describe it as a more casual form of bullet hell, where players of games like Heavy Weapon and Ikaruga will find themselves very comfortable.  Combined with a fun combat system and very silly humour that made me laugh out loud a few times, I absolutely loved this game.  However, the price might be a bit much for some, especially if they're only going to do one playthrough.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Short campaign, long replayability.

Difficulty:
Each campaign section had its own enemies with their own weapon patterns. But the inclusion of an upgrade shop made the enemies too easy, right? Well then you crank up the enemy health to 300%, enemy fire rate 300%, and your own health to 20% to get a true bullet hell experience. This creates absolute chaos and I love it.

Story:
It's a pretty standard story with plots of alien rulers, missing ships, etc. Characters are not memorable, but their design adds a charm to the game. The writing however, is pretty funny.

Visuals:
Unlike the characters, the environments were all very unique with enemies to match. Underwater enemies actually look like they belong underwater. The space environments look pretty wicked, and the projectiles are flashy and feel like they belong in a bright, chaotic space battle.

Music:
If you like upbeat, intense electronica, then you'll like this.

reviewText:
A really nice couch co-op game with a ton of excitement! Best with friends, but still a lot of fun in single player.

And the soundtrack is the best! Can't get the main theme out of my head.

If you like bullet hells with less rage and occasional multiplayer, this is your game. Graphical style is really nice and work perfectly for this kind of game. A steal for this price.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If I only had one Mech game on STEAM, this would be it. Its a great horizontal arcade 2D shooter in its own right, but the RPG elements make it unique. Has a very PS3 look and feel to it. Right off the bat I noticed the trigger buttons were my firing button, kudos. Lets face it this game is meant for a console controller, not an arcade stick. Very much in the vain of SkyForce Anniversary, the RPG elements really bring a lot of replayability to the floor. With so many 'ports' coming to STEAM, its a breath of fresh air to see a title like this one. I really don't mind pixel graphics, but so many bad ports in general. I honestly have no idea if this game is a port or an original, but I can assure you, its done right! I love a good arcade shooter, Raiden III/IV, Crimson Cover, Mushihimesama etc, but after a few continues and 15-20 minutes I'm watching the end credits. But as PC gamers we sort of want a little more depth and replayability. No its not as deep as SkyRim, nor was it ever meant to be. If you are like me, love anime, mechs and video games, its a must have!\n\n
